article:
An 'index fund' or 'index tracker' is a collective investment scheme (usually a
mutual fund or exchange-traded fund) that aims to replicate the movements of an
index of a specific financial market, or a set of rules of ownership that are
held constant, regardless of market conditions. As of 2007, index funds made up
over 11% of equity mutual fund assets in the US. [http://www.google.com/img-
res?q=graph+growth+in+popularity+of+index+funds&um=1&hl=en&client=firefox-
a&sa=N&rls=org.mozilla:en-US:official&biw=1024&bih=636&tbm=isch&tbnid=tAE4-
EV5aXWh9M:&imgrefurl=http://mjperry.blogspot.com/2008_05_25_archive.html&docid=-
e-tRJe44a-
6uGM&imgurl=http://1.bp.blogspot.com/_otfwl2zc6Qc/SD4Ogcu_l3I/AAAAAAAAEok/Agbwj-
p51og4/s400/index.bmp&w=400&h=352&ei=dKZcUN6DJcnxygGVhYHoAg&zoom=1&iact=hc&vpx=-
271&vpy=291&dur=15188&hovh=211&hovw=239&tx=154&ty=122&sig=111506616208455024527-
&page=1&tbnh=130&tbnw=148&start=0&ndsp=13&ved=1t:429,r:5,s:0,i:89&surl=1 Equity
Index Mutual Fund Assets as a Percent of Equity Mutual Fund Assets 1985-2007],
source: Investment Company Institute
headings: Comparison of index funds with index ETFs
